solution:
# Network Types Complete Exercise - COMPLETE SOLUTION

## CLASSIFICATION CRITERIA

# Networks classified by 5 criteria:
# 1. Geographic scope: Coverage area (PAN, LAN, MAN, WAN)
# 2. Ownership: Private (owned) vs Public (ISP)
# 3. Architecture: Client-server, peer-to-peer, cloud
# 4. Topology: Physical/logical layout
# 5. Purpose: Storage (SAN), Campus (CAN), general use

## PAN - PERSONAL AREA NETWORK

# Coverage: 1-10 meters
# Devices: Phone, laptop, smartwatch, headphones, fitness tracker
# Technologies: Bluetooth, NFC, Infrared, USB, Zigbee

# Bluetooth:
# - Class 2 range: 10 meters
# - Class 1 range: 100 meters
# - Speed 5.0: 50 Mbps
# - Uses: Wireless headphones, keyboards, mice, speakers

# NFC (Near Field Communication):
# - Range: Less than 10 cm
# - Speed: 424 kbps
# - Uses: Contactless payments (Apple Pay), device pairing

# USB speeds:
# - USB 2.0: 480 Mbps
# - USB 3.0: 5 Gbps
# - USB 3.1: 10 Gbps
# - USB4: 40 Gbps

# Zigbee:
# - Standard: IEEE 802.15.4
# - Range: 10-100 meters
# - Speed: 250 kbps
# - Use: IoT devices, smart home

## LAN - LOCAL AREA NETWORK

# Coverage: Single building or campus, up to few km
# Ownership: Private (organization-owned)
# Latency: Very low (<1ms)
# Devices: Computers, printers, servers, switches

# Wired Ethernet (IEEE 802.3):
# - 10BASE-T: 10 Mbps
# - 100BASE-TX: 100 Mbps (Fast Ethernet)
# - 1000BASE-T: 1 Gbps (Gigabit)
# - 10GBASE-T: 10 Gbps
# - Cables: Cat5e, Cat6, Cat6a, Cat7
# - Topology: Star with switches

# Wireless Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11):
# - 802.11b: 11 Mbps, 2.4 GHz
# - 802.11g: 54 Mbps, 2.4 GHz
# - 802.11n (Wi-Fi 4): 600 Mbps, 2.4/5 GHz
# - 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5): 6.9 Gbps, 5 GHz
# - 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6): 9.6 Gbps, 2.4/5 GHz
# - Wi-Fi 6E: 6 GHz, 9.6 Gbps
# - Wi-Fi 7 (802.11be): 46 Gbps, 2.4/5/6 GHz
# - Range: 30-100 meters indoors

# LAN Advantages:
# - High speed and low latency
# - High reliability
# - Full control over infrastructure
# - Secure (physical control)
# - Cost-effective: No monthly fees

# LAN Types by Size:
# - SOHO: 1-20 devices, single router/switch
# - SMB: 20-250 devices, multiple switches, VLANs
# - Enterprise: 250+ devices, hierarchical design, high redundancy

## WLAN - WIRELESS LAN

# Technology: Wi-Fi (802.11)
# Components:
# - Access Point (AP): Connects wireless clients to wired network
# - SSID: Service Set Identifier
# - Wireless Controller: Manages multiple APs

# Security (oldest to newest):
# 1. WEP: Obsolete, extremely insecure
# 2. WPA: Deprecated, TKIP encryption
# 3. WPA2: Current standard, AES encryption
# 4. WPA3: Latest, enhanced security (SAE)

# Authentication:
# - Personal (PSK): Pre-shared key
# - Enterprise (802.1X): RADIUS authentication

## MAN - METROPOLITAN AREA NETWORK

# Coverage: City/metro area, 5-50 km
# Size: Larger than LAN, smaller than WAN
# Ownership: Often ISP-owned, sometimes organization
# Speed: 10-100 Gbps

# Technologies:
# - Metro Ethernet: Carrier-grade Ethernet over fiber
# - WiMAX (IEEE 802.16): Mostly obsolete, replaced by LTE/5G
# - SONET/SDH: Synchronous optical networking, ring topology

# Examples:
# - Connecting multiple offices in city
# - University campus across city
# - City-wide public Wi-Fi
# - Smart city infrastructure

## WAN - WIDE AREA NETWORK

# Coverage: Cities, countries, continents (unlimited)
# Ownership: Typically leased from ISPs
# Latency: Higher than LAN (10-100+ ms)
# Speed: 1.5 Mbps (T1) to 100+ Gbps

# Leased Lines:
# - T1: 1.544 Mbps, 24 DS0 channels, North America
# - E1: 2.048 Mbps, Europe
# - T3: 44.736 Mbps
# - OC-3: 155 Mbps, OC-12: 622 Mbps
# - Dedicated, point-to-point, expensive

# Legacy Technologies:
# - Frame Relay: Packet-switching, PVCs, obsolete
# - ATM: Cell-switching, 53-byte cells, QoS, obsolete

# MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching):
# - Label-based forwarding
# - Traffic engineering
# - VPN support: L2VPN and L3VPN
# - Common for Enterprise WANs

# VPN (Virtual Private Network):
# Site-to-Site:
# - Connects two networks
# - Always-on connection
# - Router-to-router
# - Replaces expensive leased lines

# Remote Access:
# - Connects individual users
# - On-demand connection
# - Client software required
# - Secure remote work

# VPN Protocols:
# - IPsec: Most common for site-to-site
# - SSL/TLS: Remote access, browser-based
# - OpenVPN, WireGuard

# SD-WAN (Software-Defined WAN):
# - Modern approach
# - Multiple transports: MPLS, Internet, LTE, 5G
# - Application-aware routing
# - Centralized management (cloud-based)
# - Cost-effective and flexible

# Broadband Technologies:
# - Cable: DOCSIS standard, up to 10 Gbps
# - DSL: ADSL/VDSL, up to 100 Mbps
# - Fiber: FTTH/FTTP, up to 10 Gbps
# - Satellite: Starlink/HughesNet, up to 200+ Mbps
# - Cellular: 4G LTE, 5G, up to 10+ Gbps

# The Internet:
# - The largest WAN
# - Billions of devices worldwide
# - Public network
# - ISPs provide connectivity
# - TCP/IP protocol suite
# - Hierarchical structure (Tier 1, 2, 3 ISPs)
# - BGP routing between ISPs

## CAN - CAMPUS AREA NETWORK

# Coverage: Multiple buildings in close proximity, 1-5 km
# Technologies: Fiber optic backbone
# Speed: 10-100 Gbps
# Ownership: Organization-owned

# CAN vs LAN:
# CAN: Multiple buildings, fiber backbone, larger scale, complex routing
# LAN: Single building, copper cabling, smaller scale, simple switching

# Examples:
# - University campus (buildings, dorms, labs)
# - Corporate campus (multiple office buildings)
# - Hospital complex (multiple buildings)
# - Military base, Industrial park

# Architecture:
# Each building: LAN switches
# Connection: Fiber optic backbone (10-100 Gbps)

## SAN - STORAGE AREA NETWORK

# Full name: Storage Area Network
# Purpose: Dedicated high-speed network for storage devices
# Access: Block-level (not file-level)
# Network: Dedicated network, isolated from LAN
# Speed: 8-128 Gbps (Fibre Channel)

# Technologies:

# Fibre Channel (FC):
# - Dedicated FC switches and HBAs
# - Speeds: 8, 16, 32, 64, 128 Gbps
# - Very expensive cost
# - Most reliable
# - Block-level storage access

# iSCSI (Internet Small Computer System Interface):
# - SCSI over TCP/IP
# - Uses standard Ethernet
# - Cost-effective
# - Good performance (up to 100 Gbps)
# - More flexible than FC

# FCoE (Fibre Channel over Ethernet):
# - FC frames over Ethernet
# - Convergence solution
# - Requires lossless Ethernet (DCB)
# - Reduced cabling

# SAN vs NAS:
# SAN: Block-level, FC/iSCSI, dedicated network, very high speed, expensive, databases/VMs, complex
# NAS: File-level, NFS/SMB, shared LAN, high speed, moderate cost, file sharing, simple

# SAN Components:
# - Storage Array: Disk enclosure with drives, RAID
# - SAN Switch/Fabric: Fibre Channel switches
# - HBA (Host Bus Adapter): FC adapter in server
# - iSCSI Initiator: Client side
# - iSCSI Target: Storage side

# SAN Use Cases:
# - Database servers: SQL, Oracle
# - Virtualization: VMware, Hyper-V storage
# - High-performance computing
# - Backup and disaster recovery

## NETWORK COMPARISON

# Coverage (smallest to largest):
# 1. PAN: 1-10m
# 2. LAN: Building
# 3. CAN: Campus (1-5 km)
# 4. MAN: City (5-50 km)
# 5. WAN: Country/continent (unlimited)

# Ownership:
# Private (owned): PAN, LAN, CAN, SAN
# Leased (ISP): WAN, MAN
# Mixed: VPN over Internet

# Speed:
# Fastest: SAN (128 Gbps FC), CAN/MAN (100 Gbps)
# High: LAN (100 Gbps), WLAN (10+ Gbps)
# Varies: WAN (1.5 Mbps to 100+ Gbps)
# Slower: PAN (up to 50 Mbps Bluetooth 5.0)

# Cost (lowest to highest):
# Low: PAN
# Medium: LAN
# High: CAN, MAN
# Very High: SAN, WAN leased lines

## NETWORK SELECTION

# Geographic Scope:
# Single room: PAN (personal) or LAN (office)
# Single building: LAN (Ethernet) + WLAN (Wi-Fi)
# Multiple buildings (campus): CAN with fiber backbone
# Multiple cities: WAN (MPLS, VPN, SD-WAN)
# Storage needs: SAN (FC or iSCSI)

# Performance:
# Bandwidth:
# - Low (<10 Mbps): PAN
# - Medium (100 Mbps-1 Gbps): LAN, WLAN
# - High (10-100 Gbps): LAN, CAN, MAN
# - Very high (>100 Gbps): SAN

# Latency:
# - Very low (<1ms): LAN
# - Low (1-10ms): LAN, CAN
# - Medium (10-50ms): WAN (within region)
# - High (50-200ms): WAN (across continents)

# Budget:
# Initial:
# - Low: PAN (personal devices)
# - Medium: LAN (switches, cabling)
# - High: CAN (fiber backbone)
# - Very High: SAN (FC), WAN (leased lines)

# Ongoing:
# No monthly fees: PAN, LAN, CAN, SAN
# Monthly fees: WAN, MAN

# Control:
# Full control: PAN, LAN, CAN, SAN
# Shared control: WAN, MAN

# Security:
# Highest: SAN (dedicated, isolated)
# High: LAN, CAN (private, physical control)
# Medium: VPN (encrypted tunnels)
# Lower: Public Internet

## SCENARIOS

# Most expensive WAN: Leased lines (T1, T3)
# SD-WAN benefit: Application-aware routing, centralized management
# Wireless security (obsolete): WEP
# Wireless security (latest): WPA3
# Metro Ethernet service: E-Line, E-LAN
# Internet routing protocol: BGP
# Zigbee standard: IEEE 802.15.4
# Token Ring standard: 802.5 (obsolete)
# Star topology central device: Switch or hub
# Bluetooth 5.0 speed: 50 Mbps
hints: PAN: 1-10m, Bluetooth (10m Class 2, 100m Class 1, 50 Mbps), NFC (<10cm, contactless payments), USB speeds (480 Mbps/5 Gbps/10 Gbps/40 Gbps), Zigbee (802.15.4, IoT)
LAN: Single building, private, <1ms latency, Ethernet 802.3 (10/100/1000/10G BASE-T), Cat5e/6/6a/7 cables, star topology with switches

Wi-Fi 802.11: b(11 Mbps/2.4 GHz), g(54 Mbps/2.4 GHz), n/Wi-Fi 4 (600 Mbps/2.4+5 GHz), ac/Wi-Fi 5(6.9 Gbps/5 GHz), ax/Wi-Fi 6(9.6 Gbps/2.4+5 GHz), Wi-Fi 6E(6 GHz), Wi-Fi 7/802.11be(46 Gbps/2.4+5+6 GHz)
WLAN Security: WEP (obsolete), WPA (deprecated/TKIP), WPA2 (current/AES), WPA3 (latest/SAE); Authentication: Personal (PSK), Enterprise (802.1X/RADIUS); Components: AP, SSID, Wireless Controller
MAN: City 5-50 km, ISP-owned, 10-100 Gbps; Technologies: Metro Ethernet (carrier-grade), WiMAX 802.16 (obsolete), SONET/SDH (synchronous optical, ring)
WAN: Countries/continents, leased from ISPs, 10-100+ ms latency; Leased lines: T1 (1.544 Mbps/24 DS0), E1 (2.048 Mbps/Europe), T3 (44.736 Mbps), OC-3 (155 Mbps), OC-12 (622 Mbps)
WAN Technologies: Frame Relay (obsolete packet-switching/PVCs), ATM (obsolete 53-byte cells/QoS), MPLS (label-based/traffic engineering/L2VPN+L3VPN/enterprise WANs)

VPN: Site-to-Site (two networks/always-on/router-to-router/replaces leased lines), Remote Access (individual users/on-demand/client software/remote work); Protocols: IPsec (site-to-site), SSL/TLS (remote/browser)
SD-WAN: Software-Defined WAN, modern approach, multiple transports (MPLS/Internet/LTE/5G), application-aware routing, centralized cloud management, cost-effective
Broadband: Cable (DOCSIS/10 Gbps), DSL (ADSL+VDSL/100 Mbps), Fiber (FTTH+FTTP/10 Gbps), Satellite (Starlink+HughesNet/200+ Mbps), Cellular (4G LTE+5G/10+ Gbps)
Internet: Largest WAN, billions of devices, public network, ISPs provide connectivity, TCP/IP suite, hierarchical (Tier 1/2/3 ISPs), BGP routing between ISPs
CAN: Campus 1-5 km, multiple buildings, fiber optic backbone 10-100 Gbps, organization-owned; vs LAN: multiple vs single building, fiber vs copper, larger vs smaller scale, complex vs simple routing

SAN: Storage Area Network, dedicated high-speed for storage, block-level access (not file-level), isolated from LAN, 8-128 Gbps; Technologies: Fibre Channel (FC switches/HBAs/8-16-32-64-128 Gbps/expensive/most reliable), iSCSI (SCSI over TCP-IP/standard Ethernet/cost-effective/100 Gbps/flexible), FCoE (FC over Ethernet/convergence/lossless DCB/reduced cabling)

SAN vs NAS: SAN (block-level/FC+iSCSI/dedicated/very high/expensive/databases+VMs/complex), NAS (file-level/NFS+SMB/shared LAN/high/moderate/file sharing/simple); Components: Storage Array (RAID), SAN Switch/Fabric, HBA (Host Bus Adapter), iSCSI Initiator (client), iSCSI Target (storage)

Coverage: PAN (1-10m) → LAN (building) → CAN (campus 1-5 km) → MAN (city 5-50 km) → WAN (country/continent unlimited); Ownership: Private (PAN/LAN/CAN/SAN), Leased (WAN/MAN), Mixed (VPN over Internet)
Speed: Fastest (SAN 128 Gbps FC, CAN/MAN 100 Gbps), High (LAN 100 Gbps, WLAN 10+ Gbps), Varies (WAN 1.5 Mbps-100+ Gbps), Slower (PAN 50 Mbps Bluetooth 5.0)
Cost: Low (PAN), Medium (LAN), High (CAN/MAN), Very High (SAN FC equipment, WAN leased lines T1/T3); Ongoing: No fees (PAN/LAN/CAN/SAN), Monthly fees (WAN/MAN ISP charges)

Selection by geography: Single room (PAN personal or LAN office), Single building (LAN Ethernet + WLAN Wi-Fi), Campus (CAN fiber backbone), Multiple cities (WAN MPLS/VPN/SD-WAN), Storage (SAN FC or iSCSI)

Performance: Bandwidth Low<10 Mbps (PAN), Medium 100 Mbps-1 Gbps (LAN/WLAN), High 10-100 Gbps (LAN/CAN/MAN), Very High >100 Gbps (SAN); Latency <1ms (LAN), 1-10ms (LAN/CAN), 10-50ms (WAN region), 50-200ms (WAN continents)
